abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Education Rehabilitation
            Credit Project for Chad were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, project sustainability was uncertain, Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and Borrower performance in
            project implementation was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included:  a project with well-defined and limited
            objectives can succeed in an unstable country context, given
            adequate resources and supervision. Indicators of project
            success should have been addressed explicitly in the Staff
            Appraisal Report (SAR) although they were compiled from
            various sections of the SAR and reviewed consistently during
            supervision. Implementation is obviously hampered by
            frequent transfers and large-scale losses of supervisory
            staff, Government officials and trained personnel. In the
            future, emphasis should be placed not only on training
            adequate numbers of appropriate staff, but also on
            developing a policy framework that increases personnel
            stability and requires personnel changes to be based on
            sector needs. As supplementary teachers now make up 50
            percent of Chad's teaching force, measures should be
            developed to increase stability in that group as well, in
            order to sustain the benefits of investments in training and
            increase school quality. This operation was the fourth
            education project in Chad, but the first to receive a
            satisfactory rating. In part, its relative success was due
            to increased country stability, but its implementation
            record is largely the result of realistic program design, a
            flexible approach to implementation at allowed the
            adaptation of strategies to fit the evolving country and
            sector contexts and adequate Bank supervision.
